author: rapemachine90008932
content: so ummm stupid question but, if I make a smart contract and token and leave it for a while. Can I come back and edit it later?

author: bartinthetrulyepic
content: once the smart contract is deployed, it is not editable. if you wanted to make changes you would have to deploy an entirely new smart contract

author: steelyeyedspaceman
content: one can make an indexing smart contract relatively simply. Either one can emit an event when you purchase an nft/contract (then search the event list), or store it in a list in the state.. address -> list of owned contracts. The later method is more expensive. If one is feeling really cheeky, they could make 'buy' events and 'sell' events, but it requires a little more thought on the overall NFT deploy pipeline.

author: rapemachine90008932
content: thanks <@!137730961830969344> but what about when communities says stuff like "we'll be updating our crypto soon" how does that work?

author: steelyeyedspaceman
content: <@!391776424228290561> Every 'node' in the network is really a program that is interfacing with the network's protocol. These 'clients, nodes, or programs' can be upgraded

author: rapemachine90008932
content: So you would have to own the node itself?

author: rapemachine90008932
content: in order to upgrade it

author: steelyeyedspaceman
content: I may not be following exactly what you are asking.. (i'm just a hobbyist, there are lots of people here more knowledgeable here than me). If the whole network is upgrading, then all the clients (or > 51%) of them need to upgrade.

author: steelyeyedspaceman
content: If one wants to change a contract, their best bet is to deploy a new contract. Eth is generous with their architecture and offer test nets to practice on so we don't accidentally screw it up.

author: dr.mortal6969
content: Contracts deployed on a blockchain are immutable. This means that the address and the code of that Smart Contract can't be modified since it's permanently written on the blockchain. However there are ways to use a new contract instead of that one, which is similar to ‚Äúupdating‚Äù a contract.

author: dr.mortal6969
content: have you think about smart contract gas fees ?

author: dr.mortal6969
content: A simple smart contract with no complex business logic costs around $7,000. More advanced contracts cost up to $45,000 and more. It's not uncommon large organizations with specialized knowledge ask up to $100,000

author: rapemachine90008932
content: no i haven't thought about the gas fees

author: dr.mortal6969
content: it kinda expensive and also take fees percentage after the using of ur smart contracts

author: steelyeyedspaceman
content: use 'events' where you can to cut down on costs, as well as off chain storage is becoming more acceptable (think NFTs)

author: dr.mortal6969
content:
Bottom line: Although there's no avoiding gas fees if you want to use DeFi, there are ways to minimize the amount paid.
Organize transaction types efficiently. ...
Check the network for congestion and plan ahead when possible. ...
Calculate Ethereum gas fees according to the conditions.

author: bartinthetrulyepic
content: not sure if this was already answered but basically while the smart contract itself is not able to be 'updated' there could be code inside of it that can basically forward to a newer smart contract

author: bartinthetrulyepic
content: like a variable that only the smart contract owner would be able to set, that could be updated with the contract address for a newer version of the smart contract

author: rapemachine90008932
content: I like it and I hope it succeed

author: bartinthetrulyepic
content: the old smart contract would still exist, deployed on the previous address, of course... but thats how they get around that
